list.title: Question 1
list.content: What is the maximum number of electrons in the4p4p4psubshell?A.\hspace{1em}6B.\hspace{1em}10C.\hspace{1em}2D.\hspace{1em}8
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Forppp,lllis equal to 1. The number of electrons in a given subshell can be calculated using the formula:2(2l+1)=2((2)(1)+1)=62(2\,l + 1) = 2((2)(1) + 1) = 62(2l+1)=2((2)(1)+1)=6electronsThepppsubshell holds 3 orbitals. Each orbital can fit 2 electrons. Therefore,pppsubshell holds 6 electrons.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
What is the electron configuration of this orbital diagram?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e556344-f51d-45f9-8cc1-342ce8822130/images/aebba581-d5ec-4940-850d-7777dc859933/CH0262.png)

A.\hspace{1em}1s22s22p31s^2\,2s^2\,2p^31s22s22p3B.\hspace{1em}1s22p32s21s^2\,2p^3\,2s^21s22p32s2C.\hspace{1em}1s22s32p21s^2\,2s^3\,2p^21s22s32p2D.\hspace{1em}1s22s23s31s^2\,2s^2\,3s^31s22s23s3
list.markScheme:
AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The orbital diagram shows two electrons in the1s1s1sorbital, two in the2s2s2sorbital, and three singly placed in the2p2p2porbitals. This adds up to seven electrons, which is the electron count for nitrogen in its ground state. According to the Aufbau principle, the 1s orbital is filled first, followed by2s,2s,2s,and then2p.2p.2p.The Pauli exclusion principle requires that each orbital holds no more than two electrons with opposite spin, and Hund's rule explains why the three2p2p2pelectrons occupy separate orbitals with parallel spins before any pairing occurs.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e556344-f51d-45f9-8cc1-342ce8822130/images/566bc402-15c8-4c3e-ad06-0370a9a3d480/CH0262ms.png)

list.title: Question 3
list.content: Which of the following subshells contains the highest energy?A.2s\hspace{1em}2s2sB.2p\hspace{1em}2p2pC.2d\hspace{1em}2d2dD.3d\hspace{1em}3d3d
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to Aufbau’s principle, the arrangement of subshell in increasing energy is1s2s2p3s3p4s3d4p1s\  2s\  2p\  3s\  3p\  4s\  3d\  4p1s2s2p3s3p4s3d4p.Therefore, options A and B are both incorrect.Option C is incorrect because2d2d2ddoes not exist.

list.title: Question 4
list.content: What is the term for the region where there is the highest probability of finding an electron?A.\hspace{1em}OrbitalB.\hspace{1em}NucleusC.\hspace{1em}Orbital diagramD.\hspace{1em}Orbit
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice B is incorrect because electrons are not located in the nucleus. Choice C is incorrect because an orbital diagram is just a representation of electrons in an orbital. Choice D is incorrect because electrons do not have a fixed orbita around the nucleus in the quantum mechanical model. Choice A is the correct answer: orbitals are areas/ regions in space where the probability of finding an electron is very high.

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Which of the following is the correct electron configuration of a typical sodium ion?A.\hspace{1em}[Ne]3s1\ce{[Ne]}\, 3s^1[Ne]3s1B.\hspace{1em}[Ne]3s2\ce{[Ne]}\, 3s^2[Ne]3s2C.\hspace{1em}[Ne]\ce{[Ne]}[Ne]D.\hspace{1em}[Ne]2s1\ce{[Ne]}\, 2s^1[Ne]2s1
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The atomic number of sodium is 11. Its electron configuration follows the Aufbau principle, filling the electron sublevels from lowest to highest energy.Na\ce{Na}Na:1s22s22p63s11s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^11s22s22p63s1This can be rewritten in noble gas or shorthand notation by observing that the noble gas neon has the same core electron filling(Ne:1s22s22p6)(\ce{Ne}:\, 1s^2 2s^2 2p^6)(Ne:1s22s22p6).  The electron configuration of neutral sodium can be rewritten asNa\ce{Na}Na:[Ne]3s1\ [\ce{Ne}]\,3s^1[Ne]3s1The atom loses one electron to become a stable ion with a charge of 1+ (10 electrons). The removed electron is from the valence shell (the3s3s3selectron).  The electron configuration of sodium ion isNaX+\ce{Na^+}NaX+:[Ne]\ [\ce{Ne}][Ne]Alternatively, notice that sodium ion is isoelectronic with neon so mush share its electron configuration.

list.title: Question 6
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice A is incorrect because the orbital diagram does not satisfy Hund's rule wherein all orbitals must be singly occupied before pairing.Choice B is incorrect because Pauli's Exclusion principle is not obeyed by having two electrons with the same spin in one orbital.Choice C is correct because, according to Hund's rule, the orbitals must be half-filled first before pairing, and the paired orbital must have electrons in an opposite spin.Choice D is incorrect because the2s2s2sorbital must be filled first before filling the 2p orbital, as illustrated by Aufbau's Principle.

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Which of the following statements aboutX2351X223251V\ce{^{51}_{23}V}X2351​X223251​Vare correct?I.It has 23 protonsII.It has 51 nucleonsIII.It has a condensed electron configuration of [Ne]4s23d34s^2\,3d^34s23d3A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Vanadium has an atomic number of 23 therefore statement I is true. It also has a mass number of 51, therefore statement II is also true as nucleons include both protons and neutrons. Statement III is false as the closest noble gas is Ar, not Ne. The correct condensed electron configuration would be [Ar]4s23d34s^2\,3d^34s23d3. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

list.title: Question 14
list.content: Which statement about ionization energies isincorrect\textbf{incorrect}incorrect?A.\hspace{1em}First ionization energies are always higher than second ionization energiesB.\hspace{1em}It represents the energy required to remove electronsC.\hspace{1em}The general trend is that first ionization energies increase across a periodD.\hspace{1em}The general trend is that first ionization energies decrease down a group
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Second ionization energies are higher than the first as the electrons are being removed from a positive ion resulting in a stronger electrostatic attraction.First ionization energies do increase across a period due to increasing nuclear charge.First ionization energies also decrease down a group due to increased shielding (number of shells).

list.title: Question 15
list.content: State the full electron configurations of anN\ce{N}Natom andO\ce{O}Oatom.[2]Draw the orbital diagrams for anN\ce{N}Natom andO\ce{O}Oatom.[2]Compare and explain the difference between the first ionization energy of oxygen and nitrogen.[3]

list.title: Question 16
list.content: What will happen to the frequency of moving light particles if the wavelength is doubled, assuming the velocity is constant?A.\hspace{1em}The frequency will be doubledB.\hspace{1em}The frequency will decrease by halfC.\hspace{1em}The frequency will not be affectedD.\hspace{1em}The frequency will increase by four
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:There is an inverse relationship between frequency and wavelength. If the wavelength is doubled, the frequency will decrease by half. Therefore, Choices A, C, and D are all incorrect.

list.title: Question 17
list.content: Which of the following statement(s) is (are) true?I.The emission spectra are produced from a release of energy of excited electronsII.No two electrons in one atom have the same set of quantum numbersIII.The electrons in an orbital must have an opposite spinA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement I is true because emission spectra are produced when photons are released from excited electrons returning to lower energy levels.Statement II is true because this is Pauli's Exclusion principle.Statement III is also true because it is included in Pauli's Exclusion principle.

list.content: What is the ground state electron configuration of an atom of an element in Group 16 of the periodic table?A.1s22s22p2\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^21s22s22p2B.1s22s22p4\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^41s22s22p4C.1s22s22p63s23p64s23d6\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^61s22s22p63s23p64s23d6D.1s22s22p63s23p64s23d104p6\hspace{1em}1s^2\ 2s^2\ 2p^6\ 3s^2\ 3p^6\ 4s^2\ 3d^{10}\ 4p^61s22s22p63s23p64s23d104p6

list.title: Question 21
list.content: Deuterium is an isotope of hydrogen that contains one proton, one neutron, and one electron.Complete the following table.[2]ProtonsNeutronsElectronsRelative chargeRelative mass∼11836\sim\dfrac{1}{1836}∼18361​Location\\Using the following data, calculate the relative atomic mass of hydrogen correct to five decimal places, showing your work.[2]IsotopeRelative abundanceHydrogen-199.980%Deuterium0.012%Hydrogen-30.008%\\Describe the emission spectrum of the hydrogen atom.[2]Outline the difference between a continuous spectrum and a line spectrum.[1]Suggest how your answer to (b)(i) shows that energy levels are quantized.[1]
list.markScheme: All correct, two✓\checkmark✓Allow one✓\checkmark✓for one correctProtonsNeutronsElectronsRelative charge+10−1-1−1Relative mass11∼11836\sim \dfrac{1}{1836}∼18361​LocationNucleusNucleusOutside the nucleus\\99.980100×1+0.012100×2+0.008100×3=1.00028\dfrac{99.980}{100} \times 1 + \dfrac{0.012}{100} \times 2 + \dfrac{0.008}{100} \times 3 = 1.0002810099.980​×1+1000.012​×2+1000.008​×3=1.00028Correct working✓\checkmark✓Correct answer✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:To calculate the relative atomic mass, we need to multiply the isotopic masses with their relative abundances and add them together.A series of lines✓\checkmark✓that converge at higher energies.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The hydrogen emission spectrum has a series of lines that get closer together at one end. These lines represent wavelengths of light that are emitted when an electron jumps between energy levels. As electrons move further from the nucleus, the energy levels become closer in energy so the energy difference decreases and the lines are closer together and converge.In a continuous spectrum, all wavelengths are possible. In a line spectrum, only certain wavelengths are possible.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:In the hydrogen emission spectrum, only certain wavelengths of light equal to the energy difference between two energy levels are possible, forming a line spectrum. A continuous spectrum is not restricted to certain wavelengths, rather all wavelengths are possible.Since the lines are discrete and represent electron jumps between energy levels, this shows us that the energy levels are quantized.✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The hydrogen emission spectrum is a line spectrum that only contains certain wavelengths of light. The lines represent an electron releasing energy as it drops to a lower energy level, equal to the energy difference between the two energy levels. In order for the lines to be discrete, the conclusion must be made that energy levels are quantized.

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
Each element contains a different arrangement of electrons, and these electron configurations can also be represented using orbital diagrams. list.title: Question 31
list.content: Which of the following correctly compares the2s2s2sand3s3s3satomic orbitals?Average distance from the nucleusOrbital energyA.\hspace{1em}2s>3s2s > 3s2s>3s2s<3s2s < 3s2s<3sB.2s>3s2s > 3s2s>3s2s>3s2s > 3s2s>3sC.2s<3s2s < 3s2s<3s2s<3s2s < 3s2s<3sD.2s<3s2s < 3s2s<3s2s>3s2s > 3s2s>3s
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The3s3s3sorbital is larger than the2s2s2sorbital so an electron in a3s3s3sorbital is, on average, farther from the nucleus than one in a2s2s2sorbital. Additionally, the3s3s3sorbital is higher in energy because electrons in higher energy levels experience weaker electrostatic attraction to the nucleus, due to increased shielding by inner electrons and greater average distance. Therefore, both the average distance and the energy of the3s3s3sorbital are greater than those of the2s2s2sorbital.

list.title: Question 32
list.content: Which of the following ionization energies is the largest in magnitude?A.\hspace{1em}The first ionization energy of sodiumB.\hspace{1em}The second ionization energy of magnesiumC.\hspace{1em}The third ionization energy of aluminiumD.\hspace{1em}The fourth ionization energy of silicon
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Successive ionization energies are larger, as electrons are removed, there is less electron-electron repulsion, so the remaining electrons are pulled closer to the nucleus, and more energy is required to remove them.

list.title: Question 36
list.content: Which of the following represents the correct ground state electron configuration of chromium?A.1s22s22p63s23p63d44s2\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,3d^4\,4s^21s22s22p63s23p63d44s2B.1s22s22p63s23p64s24d4\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^2\,4d^41s22s22p63s23p64s24d4C.1s22s22p63s23p63d54s1\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,3d^5\,4s^11s22s22p63s23p63d54s1D.1s22s22p63s23p64s14d5\hspace{1em}1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,4s^1\,4d^51s22s22p63s23p64s14d5
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The electron configuration of chromium (Cr) is unusual because it violates the aufbau principle, which states that electrons will fill orbitals in order of increasing energy.Normally, the4s4s4sorbital would be completely filled before the3d3d3dorbital, since the4s4s4sorbital has a lower energy level than the3d3d3dorbital.The electron configuration1s22s22p63s23p63d54s11s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^6\,3d^5\,4s^11s22s22p63s23p63d54s1is more stable because it maximizes the number of half−-−filled and completely filleddddorbitals, which are energetically favorable. Half−-−filled and completely filleddddorbitals are more stable than partially filleddddorbitals, due to electron−-−electron repulsion effects.

list.title: Question 37
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The bonds inOX3\ce{O3}OX3​have bond order 1.5, as theπ\piπbonding pair is delocalized across the two bonds.The bond inOX2\ce{O2}OX2​has bond order 2. The bonds inOX3\ce{O3}OX3​are therefore weaker than those inOX2\ce{O2}OX2​and broken by a longer wavelength of light (331 nm) than the bond in inOX2\ce{O2}OX2​(241 nm).The student must provide two pieces of information: the relative bond strengths of ozone and oxygen and the correlation between energy and wavelength. Nonetheless, this question is of only moderate difficulty since it requires recall of two aspects of a key topic covered explicitly in the syllabus.

list.title: Question 38
list.content: Which statement about the first ionization energies for the elements in period 3 isincorrect?A.P\hspace{1em}\ce{P}Phas a lower first ionization energy thanS\ce{S}SbecauseS\ce{S}Shas more protonsB.S\hspace{1em}\ce{S}Shas a lower first ionization energy than P because S has greatereX−−eX−\ce{e^-}-\ce{e^-}eX−−eX−repulsionC.Na\hspace{1em}\ce{Na}Nahas the lowest first ionization energyD.Ar\hspace{1em}\ce{Ar}Arhas the highest first ionization energy
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Generally, the first ionization energy increases across a period (due to the decrease in atomic radius and the increase in nuclear charge). In period 3, Na is the first element with the lowest ionization energy, and Ar is the last element with the highest ionization energy.There are some exceptions to the trend. Phosphorus (1012 kJ mol−1^{-1}−1) has a higher ionization energy than sulfur (1000 kJ/mol), despite sulfur being further right on the periodic table.To understand this exception, we can consider the electron configuration for S,1s22s22p63s23p41s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^41s22s22p63s23p4, and P,1s22s22p63s23p31s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^31s22s22p63s23p3. In sulfur, one orbital contains paired electrons, increasing electron-electron repulsion. This repulsion lowers sulfur's ionization energy by making it easier to remove an electron, despite its higher nuclear charge.

list.title: Question 39
list.content: Which of the following species has the highest number of unpaired electrons?A.Cr\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr}CrB.CrX2+\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{2+}}CrX2+C.CrX3+\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{3+}}CrX3+D.CrX6+\hspace{1em}\ce{Cr^{6+}}CrX6+
list.markScheme: AExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Chromium is one of the exceptions to completely filling the 4sssorbital before the 3dddorbital.It has an electron configuration of[Ar]4s13d5[Ar] 4s^1  3d^5[Ar]4s13d5and all six valence electrons are unpaired. As electrons are removed to form chromium ions, the number of unpaired electrons decreases. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

list.title: Question 43
list.content: Which electron transition in the hydrogen atom would produce the shortest wavelength?A.5p⟶1s\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 1s5p⟶1sB.5p⟶2s\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 2s5p⟶2sC.5p⟶3s\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 3s5p⟶3sD.5p⟶4s\hspace{1em}5p \longrightarrow 4s5p⟶4s
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The shortest wavelength corresponds to a higher frequency and therefore a higher energy transition. The5p5p5pto1s1s1srepresents the largest energy drop and therefore would produce the shortest wavelength.

list.title: Question 44
list.content: An electron in a hydrogen atom transitions fromn=1n = 1n=1ton=4n = 4n=4, which statement below best describes the energy involved in this transition?A.\hspace{1em}Energy is absorbed in the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum.B.\hspace{1em}Energy is emitted in the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum.C.\hspace{1em}Energy is absorbed in the ultraviolet range of the electromagnetic spectrum.D.\hspace{1em}Energy is emitted in the ultraviolet range of the electromagnetic spectrum.
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Transitions from energy levelsn=2,3,4…n = 2, 3, 4\ldotsn=2,3,4…ton=1n = 1n=1represent the largest energy transitions due to the convergence of energy levels moving away from the nucleus.A transition fromn=4⟶n=1n = 4 \longrightarrow n = 1n=4⟶n=1emits in the UV range of the spectrum. Since the proposed transition is fromn=1n = 1n=1ton=4n = 4n=4, ultraviolet light is absorbed rather than emitted.

list.title: Question 46
list.content: Successive ionization energies for an unknown element are given in the table below.Ionization energy /kJmol−1\mathbf{kJ\ mol^{-1}}kJmol−1First ionization energy494Second ionization energy4562Third ionization energy6912Fourth ionization energy9543To which element the trend above for successive ionization energies belong to?A.\hspace{1em}LiB.\hspace{1em}NaC.\hspace{1em}MgD.\hspace{1em}Al
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Students must understand that patterns in successive ionization energies give evidence for the energy levels in the atom.From the given data, we can see a significant increase from first to second ionization energy. This jump between the first and second ionization energy indicates that the second electron is removed from a lower energy level. As a result, we can conclude that the element has one valence electron and belongs to group 1.The element has at least 4 electrons, so it cannot be lithium.This question is categorized as medium difficulty as the student must deduce the group of an element from its successive ionization energy data.

list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Orbital diagrams must follow three rules: the Aufbau principle, Hund's rule, and the Pauli exclusion principle.Options A and C are the orbital diagrams for copper and chromium respectively−-−the two exceptions to completely filling the4s4s4sorbital before the3d3d3dorbital.Option B is the orbital diagram for either the copper(I) ion or the zinc (II) ion as4s4s4selectrons are removed before3d3d3delectrons.This leaves Option D as the option that is not possible as it is what we would expect the orbital diagram to be for copper if it followed the trend that4s4s4sorbitals are filled before3d3d3dorbitals. As4s4s4selectrons are removed before3d3d3delectrons, this cannot be the orbital diagram for any ions either. A full3d3d3dsubshell is more stable.

list.title: Question 49
list.content: Consider the data below on the successive ionization energies forAl.\ce{Al}.Al.\enskipElectrons Removed\enskip1234Energy(kJmol−1)\textbf{Energy(kJ mol}\mathbf{^{-1}})Energy(kJ mol−1)577\enskip577\enskip5771816\enskip1816\enskip18162881\enskip2881\enskip288111600\enskip11600\enskip11600Explain why the successive ionization energies for an element increase.[1]Explain how the successive ionization energies for aluminium give evidence for its three valence electrons.[2]Using sections 1 and 2 of the data booklet, calculate the wavelength of light required to remove an electron from an aluminium atom.[3]
list.markScheme:
As electrons are removed, there is less electron- electron repulsion, so the remaining electrons are pulled closer to the nucleus and more energy is required to remove them.✓.\, \checkmark.✓There is a large increase in ionization energy between the 3rd and 4th electron, indicating that the 4th electron is removed from a different (lower/closer) energy level.✓\checkmark✓The 4th electron is removed from an energy level closer to the nucleus, with stronger forces of attraction, so aluminium has three electrons in its valence shell.✓\checkmark✓\mbox{}IE=(L)(E)⟹E=IEL=577×1036.02×1023=9.58×10−19J✓E=(h)(f)⟹f=Eh=9.58×10−196.63×10−34=1.45×1015Hz✓c=(λ)(f)⟹λ=cf=3×1081.45×1015=2.08×10−7m✓\begin{aligned}
IE &= (L)(E) \Longrightarrow E = \dfrac{IE}{L} = \dfrac{577\times 10^3}{6.02\times 10^{23}} = 9.58\times 10^{-19}\,\text{J}\, \checkmark \\
E &= (h)(f) \Longrightarrow f = \dfrac{E}{h} = \dfrac{9.58\times 10^{-19}}{6.63\times10^{-34}} = 1.45\times 10^{15}\,\text{Hz}\, \checkmark \\
c &= (\lambda)(f) \Longrightarrow \lambda = \dfrac{c}{f} = \dfrac{3\times 10^{8}}{1.45\times10^{15}} \\
&= \answer{2.08\times 10^{-7}\text{m}}\,\checkmark
\end{aligned}IEEc​=(L)(E)⟹E=LIE​=6.02×1023577×103​=9.58×10−19J✓=(h)(f)⟹f=hE​=6.63×10−349.58×10−19​=1.45×1015Hz✓=(λ)(f)⟹λ=fc​=1.45×10153×108​=2.08×10−7m​✓​

list.content: The wavelength of light emitted for then=∞→1n=\infty \rightarrow 1n=∞→1transition for an electron in a zinc atom is296nm.296\, nm.296nm.Define first ionization energy.[2]Write an equation that represents the first ionization energy of zinc.[1]Using sections 1 and 2 of the data booklet, calculate the first ionization energy of zinc in kJ mol−1^{-1}−1.[3]
list.markScheme:
The minimum energy required to remove one mole of electrons✓\checkmark✓from one mole of gaseous atoms.✓\checkmark✓Zn(g)→ZnX+(g)+eX−✓\ce{Zn(g) -> Zn+(g) + e-}\, \checkmarkZn(g)​ZnX+(g)+eX−✓State symbols required\mbox{}c=(λ)(f)⟹f=cλ=3×108m s−1296×10−9m=1.01×1015Hz✓E=(h)(f)⟹E=(6.63×10−34J s)(1.01×1015s−1)=6.72×10−19J✓IE=(L)(E)⟹IE=(6.02×1023)(6.72×10−19)=404544J mol−1=405kJ mol−1✓\begin{aligned}
c &= (\lambda)(f) \Longrightarrow f = \dfrac{c}{\lambda}=\dfrac{3\times10^8\text{m s}^{-1}}{296\times 10^{-9}\text{m}} = 1.01\times10^{15}\text{Hz}\, \checkmark  \\
E &= (h)(f) \Longrightarrow E = (6.63\times 10^{-34}\text{J s})(1.01\times 10^{15}\text{s}^{-1}) = 6.72\times 10^{-19}\,\text{J}\,\checkmark \\
IE &= (L)(E) \Longrightarrow IE = (6.02\times 10^{23})(6.72\times 10^{-19}) = 404544\,\text{J mol}^{-1} \\
&= \answer{405\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1}}\,\checkmark
\end{aligned}cEIE​=(λ)(f)⟹f=λc​=296×10−9m3×108m s−1​=1.01×1015Hz✓=(h)(f)⟹E=(6.63×10−34J s)(1.01×1015s−1)=6.72×10−19J✓=(L)(E)⟹IE=(6.02×1023)(6.72×10−19)=404544J mol−1=405kJ mol−1​✓​Further explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}Further explanation:​Ionization energy is the energy required to move an electron from the ground state to the infinite level and so can be expressed asn=1→∞n = 1\rightarrow \inftyn=1→∞(requiring the same energy as would be emitted for the reverse process, 296 nm).L refers to Avogadro's number (NA_AA​).

list.title: Question 51
list.content: Which of the following does NOT have two valence electrons?A.\hspace{1em}Al+^++B.\hspace{1em}ZnC.\hspace{1em}CaD.\hspace{1em}Sc3+^{3+}3+
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Electron configuration of Al+^++: [Ne]3s23s^23s2Electron configuration of Zn: [Ar]4s24s^24s23d103d^{10}3d10Electron configuration of Ca: [Ar]4s24s^24s2Electron configuration of Sc: [Ar]4s24s^24s23d13d^13d1.Sc will lose 2 electrons in the 4s sublevel and 1 from the 3d sublevel, leaving a complete 3rd energy level with 8 valence electrons in Sc3+^{3+}3+(1s22s22p63s23p61s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^61s22s22p63s23p6).

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/89bd9bcb-c836-45ae-92f4-7c208e7e6ff5/images/116855d7-2a12-459d-ac3b-c43a03ebefb5/image.png)

list.title: Question 53
list.content: Which of the following statements aboutppporbitals are correct?I.A2p2p2porbital has the same shape as a3p3p3porbital.II.Electrons in the2p2p2porbital are, on average, closer to the nucleus than electrons in the3p3p3porbital.III.The angle between thepxp_xpx​andpyp_ypy​orbitals is90∘.90^\circ.90∘.A.\hspace{1em}I and IIB.\hspace{1em}II and IIIC.\hspace{1em}I and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Allppporbitals share the same fundamental dumbbell shape, regardless of their energy level. A2p2p2pand a3p3p3porbital have identical shapes but differ in size and energy: the3p3p3porbital is larger and has higher energy. Statement I is correct.While2p2p2pand3p3p3porbitals belong to different energy levels, electrons in a2p2p2porbital are, on average, found closer to the nucleus than those in a3p3p3porbital. This is because as the energy level increases, the average distance between the electron and the nucleus increases as well.  Statement II is also correct.Finally, the threeppporbitals(px,py,andpz)(p_x, p_y,\text{ and } p_z)(px​,py​,andpz​)are oriented along mutually perpendicular axes in three−-−dimensional space. The angle between any two of them, such aspxp_xpx​andpy,p_y,py​,is90∘.90^\circ.90∘.Statement III is correct.

list.title: Question 54
list.content: How many fully occupiedppporbitals are present in a ground–\text{--}–state arsenic (As) atom?A.\hspace{1em}2B.\hspace{1em}3C.\hspace{1em}6D.\hspace{1em}7
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:From its placement in Period 4 of the periodic table, arsenic will have two completely filledpppsubshells, or 6 filledppporbitals. The condensed electron configuration of arsenic is[Ar]4s23d104p3.[\text{Ar}]\ 4s^2\ 3d^{10}\ 4p^3.[Ar]4s23d104p3.Hund's rule reminds us that the three valencepppelectrons in arsenic will singly–\text{--}–occupy the three4p4p4porbitals. There will be 6 fully occupiedppporbitals.

AExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Manganese atoms have 25 electrons and have the electron configurationMn:1s22s22p63s23p64s23d51s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 4s^2 3d^51s22s22p63s23p64s23d5according to the aufbau principle. For Mn, the two electrons are lost from the4s4s4ssublevel to form the ionMnX2+\ce{Mn^2+}MnX2+.MnX2+\ce{Mn^{2+}}MnX2+:1s22s22p63s23p63d51s^2 2s^2 2p^6 3s^2 3p^6 3d^51s22s22p63s23p63d5To determine the number of unpaired electrons, we can draw the orbital box diagram and use Hund's law which maximizes the number of unpaired electrons in partially filled sublevels.

list.content:
The graph below shows the successive ionization energy data for an unknown metal M.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/52199042-cddb-421f-b65d-11e90428d392/images/555bf712-15ca-47f4-8685-1f60dc9bef9a/CH1251.png)

This places it in group 1 of the periodic table. In group 1 metals, the second electron lies in an inner energy level, much closer to the nucleus and much more difficult to remove, which explains the sudden increase in ionization energy.A group 1 metal forms a monovalent cation,MX+\ce{M^+}MX+, which bonds ionically with oxide,OX2−\ce{O^{2-}}OX2−. To achieve charge balance, twoMX+\ce{M^+}MX+ions combine with oneOX2−\ce{O^{2-}}OX2−, giving the formulaMX2O\ce{M2O}MX2​O.This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must deduce the group of the metal to figure out the formula of the compound formed with oxygen.

list.title: Question 63
list.content:
Which of the following best explains why dark lines appear in the following spectrum?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a5365ef0-5209-4ec6-ac9b-a2122f77697a/images/9e7287da-5026-4ca4-8933-7137e113e049/CH2145.png)

A.\hspace{1em}Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons fall to lower energy levels.B.\hspace{1em}Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.C.\hspace{1em}Photons of specific energies are absorbed as electrons fall to lower energy levels.D.\hspace{1em}Photons of specific energies are emitted as electrons are excited to higher energy levels.
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​Dark lines in an absorption spectrum are caused by electrons in atoms absorbing photons of specific energies. These energies correspond to the difference between allowed energy levels in the atom. When atoms absorb those photons, the electrons are excited to higher energy levels, and the absorbed wavelengths are missing from the observed spectrum, creating dark lines.Some answers might seem tempting but are incorrect. For example, photons are not emitted when electrons are excited because energy must be absorbed for an electron to move to a higher level. Likewise, when electrons fall to lower energy levels, they emit photons, which is how emission spectra are formed. Suggesting that photons are absorbed while electrons fall is inaccurate, since falling to a lower energy level releases energy rather than requiring it.

list.title: Question 64
list.content: The first ionization energy of rubidium is403kJ mol−1.403\,\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.403kJ mol−1.What is the wavelength of convergence for the rubidium atomic spectrum?A.2970nm\hspace{1em}2970\,\text{nm}2970nmB.297nm\hspace{1em}297\,\text{nm}297nmC.2.97×10−4m\hspace{1em}2.97 \times 10^{-4}\,\text{m}2.97×10−4mD.4.93×10−31m\hspace{1em}4.93 \times 10^{-31}\,\text{m}4.93×10−31m
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The convergence limit in an atomic spectrum corresponds to the energy required to remove an electron from the ground state of the atom, which is the first ionization energy. To use this value, it must first be expressed per atom rather than per mole:Ephoton=IENA=403×103J mol−16.02×1023mol−1=6.69×10−19JE_\ce{photon} = \dfrac{\textrm{IE}}{N_A} = \dfrac{403\times 10^3\text{\ J mol}^{-1}}{6.02\times 10^{23}\text{\ mol}^{-1}} = 6.69\times 10^{-19}\text{\ J}Ephoton​=NA​IE​=6.02×1023mol−1403×103J mol−1​=6.69×10−19JThis is the energy of a single photon at the convergence limit. Using the relationshipE=hcλ,E = \dfrac{hc}{λ},E=λhc​,the wavelength can be determined.λ=hcE=(6.63×10−34J s)(3.00×108m s−1)6.69×10−19J=2.97×10−7m=297nm\lambda = \dfrac{hc}{E} = \dfrac{(6.63\times 10^{-34}\,\text{J s})(3.00\times 10^8\,\text{m s}^{-1})}{6.69\times 10^{-19}\,\text{J}} = 2.97\times 10^{-7}\,\text{m} = \answer{297\,\text{nm}}λ=Ehc​=6.69×10−19J(6.63×10−34J s)(3.00×108m s−1)​=2.97×10−7m=297nm​The question is of medium difficulty because it requires students to connect the concept of ionization energy with the convergence limit, perform a unit conversion from per mole to per photon, and express the final result using the correct SI prefix.

The successive ionization energies for an unknown element are shown in the graph below. Which of the following statements regarding this element are correct?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2db804f3-104c-455a-aca4-896f6a765086/images/2e72a968-a136-4f83-8d80-c2744eefff9a/CH0778.png)

I.\hspace{1.em}Removal of the 4th electron is from a different energy level than the first 3 electrons.II.\hspace{0.7em}This element belongs in Group 13 on the periodic table.III.\hspace{0.4em}The effective nuclear charge is decreasing with the removal of successive electrons.A.\hspace{1em}I, II, and IIIB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and III only
list.markScheme: BExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​There is a disproportionate increase in ionization energy between the removal of the 3rd and 4th electron. Therefore, this element has 3 valence electrons, and the removal of the 4th electron would come from a lower energy level, and the element belongs in Group 13.With the removal of each subsequent electron, the remaining electrons experience less interference with one another and will experience a greater pull from the nucleus.

list.content: Which statements about successive ionization energies of sodium are correct?I.\hspace{1.em}They show an increasing trend as the number of electrons removed increases.II.\hspace{0.7em}There is a significant jump from the second to the third ionization energy.III.\hspace{0.4em}There is a significant jump from the ninth to the tenth ionization energy.A.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Successive ionization energies (IEn\ce{IE}_nIEn​) always increase as electrons are removed from an increasingly positive ion and from orbitals of lower energy, so statement I is correct.Sodium has the ground−-−state configuration1s22s22p63s1.1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^1.1s22s22p63s1.The largest jump for Na occurs when you cross from removing the valence electron to removing a core electron. For Na,IE1\ce{IE}_1IE1​removes the3s3s3selectron;IE2\ce{IE}_2IE2​begins removingn=2n=2n=2core electrons. Thus the big discontinuity is betweenIE1\ce{IE}_1IE1​andIE2,\ce{IE}_2,IE2​,(not betweenIE2\ce{IE}_2IE2​andIE3.\ce{IE}_3.IE3​.Statement II is incorrect.After nine electrons have been removed(IE1(\ce{IE}_1(IE1​throughIE9),\ce{IE}_9),IE9​),the remaining configuration is1s2.1s^2.1s2.The tenth ionization must remove a1s1s1selectron (crossing from then=2n=2n=2shell into then=1n=1n=1shell), which requires a dramatically larger energy. Therefore there is a second clear jump fromIE9\ce{IE}_9IE9​toIE10,\ce{IE}_{10},IE10​,so statement III is correct.This question is categorized as medium difficulty as students must be able to deduce the pattern for successive ionization energies of a given atom.

list.title: Question 71
list.content: The table below shows the successive ionization energies of two elements X and Y.Number of electrons removedIonization energy of X / kJ mol−1\mathbf{^{-1}}−1Ionization energy of Y / kJ mol−1\mathbf{^{-1}}−1149610002456222523691033574954345565133547004616613849672011727107Which is the correct formula for the compound formed between X and Y?A.XX2YX3\hspace{1em}\ce{X2Y3}XX2​YX3​B.XY\hspace{1em}\ce{XY}XYC.XX2Y\hspace{1em}\ce{X2Y}XX2​YD.XYX2\hspace{1em}\ce{XY2}XYX2​
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The student must deduce the corresponding group of elements X and Y from the successive ionization energies given. An element's successive ionization energies increase as more energy is needed to remove electrons.  As the ion becomes more positive, it will take more energy to remove the next electron.  Successive ionization energies always increase. When the next electron is in a shell closer to the nucleus, the successive ionization energy will increase sharply because there is less shielding of the nuclear charge and because the distance between the electron and nucleus is smaller.In the table provided, the largest jump in the ionization energy for element X occurs betweenIE1IE_1IE1​(first ionization energy) andIE2IE_2IE2​(second ionization energy). This must correspond to a change in energy level. So, the atom of the element must have one valence electron and belong to group 1. In the case of Y, the largest jump in the ionization energy occurs betweenIE6IE_6IE6​(sixth ionization energy) andIE7IE_7IE7​(seventh ionization energy). So, the atom of the element must have six valence electrons and belong to group 16.X forms cations with one positive charge whereas Y forms ions with two negative charges. As a result, the combination ofXX+\ce{X+}XX+andYX2−\ce{Y^{2-}}YX2−isXX2Y.\ce{X2Y}.XX2​Y.This question is categorized as a medium as the student must use the information from successive ionization energies to deduce the corresponding group for the elements and then figure out how these are combined together.

You can useAas the symbol for the unknown element.[2]Identify the period 3 element and explain how the ionization data shown above supports your response.[3]Explain why the ionization data increases as subsequent electrons are removed from the atom.[1]Write the electron configuration for the commonly formed ion of this period 3 element.[1]The diagram below shows the first ionization energies of the elements across period 3.

Explain how the first ionization data shown can be used to support the existence of thesssandpppsublevels of period 3.[4]Explain why argon has such a high first ionization energy.[1]
list.markScheme: AX2+(g)→AX3+(g)+eX−✓✓\ce{A^2+(g) -> A^3+(g) + e-}\,\checkmark\checkmarkAX2+(g)​AX3+(g)+eX−✓✓Award M2 for state symbols.Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Ionization energy is the energy required to remove an electron from a ground−-−state gas−-−phase atom or ion. The removal of the third successive electron would come from the ion of the element that has already lost 2 electrons (AX2+\ce{A^{2+}}AX2+). Removal of the third electron would change the ion toAX3+\ce{A^{3+}}AX3+.Magnesium  / Mg✓\checkmark✓large jump between 2nd^{nd}ndand 3rd^{rd}rdionization energy, 3rd^{rd}rdelectron from inner energy level✓\checkmark✓two valence electrons✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Looking at the graph, there is a larger step (nonlinear) increase in the subsequent ionization energies for the removal of the third electron. This means the first two electrons are removed from the valence energy level, while the third is removed from an inner energy level, in this case the second energy level since the element is in period 3.more positively changed ion, stronger attraction to the nucleus✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Since ionization energy is the energy required to completely move the electron from the atom or ion, as the charge on the nucleus increases, the ionization energy must therefore increase.1sX22sX22pX6\ce{1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6}1sX22sX22pX6✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The period 3 element is magnesium with two valence electrons in the3s3s3ssublevel. Losing these two electrons leaves a the period 2 energy level, withsssandpppsublevels complete.drop in ionization energy from Mg to Al✓\checkmark✓electrons in3p3p3psubshell partially shielded by3s3s3selectrons✓\checkmark✓drop in the ionization energy moving from P to S✓\checkmark✓fourth electron in3p3p3psubshell experiences increasedeX−−eX−\ce{e-}-\ce{e-}eX−−eX−repulsion✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:The trend of ionization energy across period 3 is generally upward due to the increasing nuclear charge pulling the outer electrons closer. However, the data also show irregularities that can only be explained by sublevels. The first occurs between magnesium and aluminium: in aluminium, the electron removed is from a3p3p3porbital, which lies at slightly higher energy and is shielded by the inner 3s orbital. This makes it easier to remove than the3s3s3selectron in magnesium. A second dip occurs between phosphorus and sulfur. Phosphorus has three unpaired3p3p3pelectrons, but sulfur has a fourth3p3p3pelectron that must pair with one of the others. The repulsion between two electrons in the same orbital lowers the energy required to remove one, creating the observed decrease. These two dips are direct experimental evidence that period 3 contains both3s3s3sand3p3p3psublevels.Ar has highest effective nuclear charge , same shielding✓\checkmark✓Further Explanation‾\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}Further Explanation​:Argon lies at the end of period 3, where the nuclear charge is greatest. Its outer electrons are still in then=3n=3n=3shell, but they experience a strong effective nuclear charge because shielding from inner electrons is relatively constant across the period. This strong attraction between nucleus and outer3p3p3pelectrons requires much more energy to remove them, so argon shows the highest first ionization energy of period 3.

list.title: Question 73
list.content: Which of the following statements about electron spin is correct?I.Unpaired electrons occupy separate orbitals within a sublevel before pairing occurs.II.Two electrons in the same orbital must have parallel spins.III.Spin is an intrinsic property of electrons that allows two electrons to occupy the same orbital.A.\hspace{1em}I and IIB.\hspace{1em}II and IIIC.\hspace{1em}I and IIID.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​According to Hund's Rule, electrons fill orbitals of the same sublevel singly and with parallel spins before any pairing occurs. This minimizes electron-electron repulsion and leads to a more stable, lower-energy configuration. Statement I is correct.Electrons in the same orbital must have opposite spins, not parallel spins, to satisfy the Pauli Exclusion Principle, which prevents two electrons in the same orbital from having identical properties. Statement II is incorrect.Spin is an intrinsic property of electrons that allows them to share an orbital, as long as their spins are opposite (↑\uparrow↑and↓\downarrow↓). This difference in spin enables two electrons to occupy the same spatial region without violating exclusion rules. Statement III is correct.

list.markScheme: XX+(g)→XX2+(g)+eX−\ce{X^+(g) -> X^{2+}(g) + e^-}XX+(g)​XX2+(g)+eX−✓\checkmark✓State symbols must be shown.Further explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}Further explanation:​Second ionization energy is the energy required to remove one mole of electrons from one mole of singly positive gaseous ions.element X has 6 valence electrons✓\checkmark✓large jump between 6th and 7th IE✓\checkmark✓Further explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}Further explanation:​There is a large increase moving from the 6th IE to the 7th IE. This indicates that the 7th electron must be removed from a lower energy level closer to the nucleus as substantially more energy is required to remove the 7th electron.value between 2.6 and 3.4✓\checkmark✓smaller atom has higher electronegativity✓\checkmark✓Further explanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Further explanation:}}Further explanation:​Element Y lies in the same group and below element X. Therefore, element Y has more energy levels in its atom than element X. Electronegativity is the attraction the atom of an element has for the shared pair of electrons in a covalent bond. This attraction will increase when there are fewer energy levels; hence electrons are closer to the nucleus or the atom, and the element has a higher electronegativity value.  The most electronegative atom in Group 16 is oxygen with 3.4.

list.title: Question 77
list.content: Two elements, X and Y, have the following successive ionization energies (inkJ mol−1):\text{kJ mol}^{-1}):kJ mol−1):Element1st2nd3rd4th5th6thX73814517733105431363018020Y1012190729144964624721267What is the most likely formula of the compound formed when X and Y combine?A.XY\hspace{1em}\ce{XY}XYB.XX2YX3\hspace{1em}\ce{X2Y3}XX2​YX3​C.XX3YX2\hspace{1em}\ce{X3Y2}XX3​YX2​D.XYX2\hspace{1em}\ce{XY2}XYX2​
list.markScheme: CExplanation:‾\textrm{\underline{Explanation:}}Explanation:​First, the student must use the information about successive ionization energies to deduce the group of both elements. For element X, there is a significant jump in ionization energy between the second and third ionization energies (from1451kJ mol−11451\text{kJ mol}^{-1}1451kJ mol−1to7733kJ mol−1),7733\text{ kJ mol}^{-1}),7733kJ mol−1),indicating that the first two electrons are valence electrons. Therefore, X has two valence electrons and belongs to Group 2. For element Y, a large jump occurs between the fifth and sixth ionization energies (from6247kJ mol−16247\text{ kJ mol}^{-1}6247kJ mol−1to21267kJ mol−1),21267\text{ kJ mol}^{-1}),21267kJ mol−1),suggesting that the first five electrons are valence electrons. Thus, Y has five valence electrons and belongs to Group 15.Second, the student must determine the preferred charge of each of the elements to find the most likely compound that they would form. Element X, with two valence electrons, will likely lose both to form theXX2+\ce{X^2+}XX2+ion, while element Y, with five valence electrons, will likely gain three electrons to form theYX3−\ce{Y^3-}YX3−ion. To balance the charges in a neutral compound, threeXX2+\ce{X^2+}XX2+ions will combine with twoYX3−\ce{Y^3-}YX3−ions, resulting in the formulaXX3YX2.\ce{X3Y2}.XX3​YX2​.This question is categorized as medium difficulty because it requires analyzing ionization energy trends, deducing ionic charges, and balancing charges to determine the correct formula of the compound.

list.title: Question 79
list.content: Which electron transition in the hydrogen atom emission spectrum emits radiation with the highest frequency?A.n=1⟶n=7\hspace{1em}n=1\longrightarrow n=7n=1⟶n=7B.n=7⟶n=1\hspace{1em}n=7 \longrightarrow n=1n=7⟶n=1C.n=5⟶n=2\hspace{1em}n=5 \longrightarrow n=2n=5⟶n=2D.n=4⟶n=3\hspace{1em}n=4 \longrightarrow n=3n=4⟶n=3
list.markScheme:
BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:To answer this question, students must differentiate emission (electrons decaying to a lower energy level) from absorption (electrons promoted to higher energy levels).Students should also recall the relationship between frequency and energy (E∝fE \propto fE∝f). The highest frequency corresponds to the highesy energy transition.  According to the Bohr model, thediscrete energy levels in the hydrogen spectrum converge at higher energies. Of the three emissions proposed, the one with the greatest frequency/energy isn=7⟶n=1.n=7 \longrightarrow n=1.n=7⟶n=1.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/89299878-7c02-447d-9568-fe86fcf00643/images/1fae25df-afde-432d-9d9e-b4c45710afca/CH0994.JPEG)

This question is categorized as hard as students compare transitions based on their knowledge of the hydrogen energy level diagram.

list.title: Question 80
list.content: Which electron transition in a hydrogen atom emits the longest wavelength of light?A.n=3\hspace{1em}n = 3n=3ton=2n = 2n=2B.n=4\hspace{1em}n = 4n=4ton=3n = 3n=3C.n=5\hspace{1em}n = 5n=5ton=4n = 4n=4D.n=2\hspace{1em}n = 2n=2ton=1n = 1n=1
list.markScheme:
CExplanation:‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}Explanation:​The electronic energy levels for the hydrogen atom converge at high energy (furthest from the nucleus), wheren=1n = 1n=1is closest to the nucleus. A simple diagram can be drawn to show the relative energy levels.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e38802a0-9d42-4913-b9b7-de2c97c3a807/images/a330f257-07c0-49ca-84ff-4a03ecd5af38/CH2032.png)

Each transition is indicated with an arrow, where the longest arrow equates to the highest energy. Energy and the wavelength of light are inversely proportional as follows:E=hcλE = \dfrac{hc}{\lambda}E=λhc​Therefore, a higher energy has a lower wavelength (and vice versa). For this question, we are looking for the shortest arrow which is the lowest energy and the longest wavelength (so,n=5n= 5n=5ton=4).n = 4).n=4).
